I was at that Worcester show! The fumble to Born to Run was so weird – and he handled it with humility and humor. It was also the first time my wife had heard the Detroit medley, and she was absolutely blown away.
I love this song. I’ve always considered it a bit of a Brian Wilson pastiche.

I’ve always seen this as a hopeful song. To me, the narrator has hopes, talents and ambitions. He could pull out of town and move on to a bigger and better world, but his comfort and familiarity with his current world won’t let him. He prefers the simpler existence. maybe it’s a bigger fish in a smaller pond thing. Or maybe it’s just a “the devil you know” thing. Bottom line is, I think the guys going to be alright— it’s just a matter of if ge makes that leap or not.
“6 ft., 3…Eddie ‘Kingfish’ Manion!”–Love seeing Eddie play the tenon sax and singing the chorus of “Ghosts” w/ Bruce and Steve at T-Moblile Park (K.C.) on this date in 2023. So much joy and fun!
It’s a tale about him coming out of his depression.

Bruce equates his feelings for his bartender / confidant (you’ll tell your bartender things you won’t even tell your doctor) with eternal, divine images and prayers. He’s saying that he sees salvation in her. Something or someone that great must be earned.
Love the duet with Melissa.

I really love and agree with your analysis of Moonlight Motel, I love the way you broke down the verse about the shot, and the symbolism of spilled liquid . The song is so beautiful. Thanks so much!

P.S.:

> … “four different layers and interpretations of death and resurrection” …

I think these are all in there as allusions from BS to his audience, but I think by the end of the song we can look back and know that, within the story, each instance of “everything dies … comes back” is primarily referring to the would-be victim, i.e., it is the speaker trying to convince the girl that what he is planning is OK, that what he is planning to do to the would-be victim is not the end of the world (everybody dies; the guy is going to die anyway; maybe it’s not that big of a deal, maybe he will be OK in the end).

If my previous comment is accurate, then he is trying to convince the girl to help, possibly using/misusing common religious notions (possibly cynically) to help make his case. If my previous comment is not accurate, then he is just trying to convince her that what he is planning is not so bad, and she should stick with him because the future is brighter (and possibly he is also trying to convince himself, i.e., talk himself into it).

(So, maybe five, six, or seven layers? Hell of a song.)

P.P.S.: I have not been a big BS fan up until now. Until about a week ago, I had only heard Levon Helm’s version of this song in the documentary made toward the end of his life. About a week ago, the 90’s The Band version showed up on youtube, and I went down a rabbit hole of listening to different versions, found out it is actually a BS song, looked up “the chicken man”, yadda yadda, ended up here. At first I thought the BS original was kind of blah, until I got more into figuring out the lyrics. Now the Levon/Band version seems like it’s missing the point (or maybe Levon was going for sort of a Highwayman-type murdering-outlaws-are-cool vibe, which seems pretty blah at this point).
“Come closer”. Those background vocals play tricks on your ears.
Patti says, “Lose it”, at 2:44.

> …”the glaring mistake in the final chorus!”…

I’m not sure this was a mistake. I think he might have been trying to add an additional twist to the story. I think he is saying something like “set it up pretty” or “set up pretty”. I think the backing vocals are saying the same thing. (Maybe BS wasn’t entirely happy with his idea/words, so maybe it is a bit less clearly sung?) I think the speaker might ultimately be trying to convince the girl to help with the job/setup, i.e., to be bait. I think BS might be trying to morph the concept of “fix your hair up” to the concept of “set the job up” or “set the guy up”, e.g., get him into the hotel room (and I’ll do the rest).

I don’t think you say “put your makeup on” to your girlfriend/wife; I think this is something that a pimp says to a prostitute, or a director says to a performer.

I think BS sort of tricks us with the first verse and chorus, making us think this is a sort of “the world’s going to hell; let’s be merry, for tomorrow we die” type of song, but as the song goes on, I think we progressively learn that the speaker is more part of the problem than someone who is trying to escape.
Such a sad story! I hope he and Bruce can reconnect. That would give it a happy ending.

I normally absolutely love your eloquent and insightful analyses of Bruce’s songs, but I respectfully disagree with your lack of enthusiasm for this one as I feel it’s one of the best on the album and *possibly* one of the best of the decade.

A few points on the lyrics…

When you described the lines, “You’ll be fine long as your pretty face holds out/Then it’s gonna get pretty cold out” as “a prediction and a warning delivered with sadness and affection,” I think something vital was being missed. In my not-so-humble opinion, these lines are delivered not with sadness but with a sneer, not with affection but with anger… and this is exhilarating precisely because it’s so uncharacteristic of our guy. Chief among Bruce’s many considerable strengths as an artist is his innate empathy and compassion, his humanism. He cares about the characters in his songs and his lyrics often possess a deep psychological awareness for how and why essentially good people can do essentially bad things. In this song, though, he’s displaying a remarkably rare emotion for him: disdain.

Referring to earlier lyrics, you commented, “Reading those lines, it would be easy to hear spite and bitterness…” and I’m going to suggest it “would be easy to hear” spite because spite is exactly what we’re hearing. Given how Bruce was feeling about America’s political situation at the time when MAGIC was released and given the thematic and emotional focus of several other songs on the album, I think Bruce was punching hard at what he perceived as a reckless abuse of power.

Rather than make song overtly political, though, he uses the metaphor of a failed relationship with a self-absorbed young woman to vent his fury. Hence, he refers to the woman’s “smiles as thin as those dusky blue skies” since a “thin” smile is known to be an insincere one, a polite masking of one’s true emotions and intentions. His lack of generosity in the song is most uncharacteristic and I think it gives the song a force, a bite, it would otherwise lack.

Oh, as for that final verse… With regards to “Like a thief on a Sunday morning/It all falls apart with no warning,” you ask, “but what exactly is it about Sundays that poses a danger to thieves?” I think there may have been a subtle but crucial misunderstanding of the line’s meaning. It’s not that a Sunday morning poses a danger to thieves, it’s that thieves on a Sunday morning pose a danger to their targets.

A thief is *far* likelier to target a house on a Saturday night because that’s when the occupants of the house are out at a bar or on a date or attending a party and so on. Going into the house in the dark of night also provides a cloak of secrecy to the thief. But for a thief coming into your house on a Sunday *morning* that causes things to “fall apart with no warning.” Who ever imagines a thief to invade their home in broad daylight when there’s an excellent chance the house will have *at least* one person home? Again, this is Bruce employing a Dylanesque snarl at someone (ostensibly a woman with a “pretty face” but really a slick, irresponsible politician) that they’re going to be hit hard because “What goes around, it comes around.”

Finally, and *hopefully* not to sound like a pedantic jerk — too late, I’m sure! — but here’s a thought about the “Your cinnamon sky’s gonna candy-apple green” line. A “cinnamon sky” refers to a sky with a warm, reddish-brown hue, one usually seen at sunset. It can be quite soft and soothing. But a candy-*apple* green? Most people think a red apple simply looks more tasty and inviting than does a green one. In comparison to a warm, reddish-brown sunset, a candle-apple one could easily seem cold and strange (How many times have you seen a green sky?), certainly not reassuring. But why did Bruce choose the color green as opposed to, say, the more ominous black? Eh, probably just because it rhymed easily with “your little flying machine.”

And not to put too fine a point on it, but I think he describes the machine/plane as “little” just to get in one final swipe at the object of his disgust. Pissed off and unapologetic about it, he can’t resist a parting shot. I can practically see him dismissively waving his hand and scoffing about “your *little* flying machine”… that will, of course, soon be comin’ down.

All that said, personal taste is, well, personal. We just responded quite differently to this song. And maybe I simply had way too much time on my hands to write such a lengthy comment. Thank you for taking the time to read this.

In any case, I’m excited to one day read your take on This Hard Land!

Well done, Ken — this was a lovely and insightful piece about what I consider to be one of my top five tracks on, er, TRACKS. “Linda Let Me Be the One” has such an evocative sense of aching longing and romanticism, so much so that I can *easily* forgive its occasionally lyrical shortcomings.

I love this blog so much. It’s an absolute gift to those of us who remain enraptured by Bruce’s art. Thank you for so much, Ken!
Ken, You are not a “Boomer”. The photographer got it wrong.
A huge fan for over fifty years and only heard this song for the first time today. Wow is right – I will be stuck on this one for some time now!

For me, the key to the seemingly strange “shoes” part is the “again”. Just as he wants to sleep tonight AGAIN in her arms – because that’s what he did in the past – he wants to drive all night AGAIN just to buy her some shoes – again suggesting he did that in the past too. You can imagine her at some point when they were a couple having said she wants a particular pair but there aren’t any available nearby so he decides to travel a huge distance overnight to go and get them for her. You can also imagine her being blown away by his crazy gesture of love and how great her delighted reaction must have made him feel – he wants to get back to that feeling of her seeing him as this crazy, romantic guy who’ll do anything to make her happy.

So glad to find your analysis of this song. Just heard it for the first time today. Since you mentioned the timing of the song, it makes me think of two things – the “public service announcement” that Bruce would do during the Rising Tour in which he’d talk about the power to send our sons and daughters to war being a sacred trust (“In this house our sons and daughters are spilled like wine”) and the cruelty and deception captured in the title track from “Magic” by which time Bruce’s Rising era concerns had been borne out beyond all of our worst fears. Thanks as always, Ken. I so appreciate your fine work.

“We are abruptly evicted from the sweet comfort of the country…Springsteen’s music takes us back to the streets, which are dirty and cluttered with frightful sights.” An excerpt from Jack Lloyd’s review of “Greetings”. Good insights all through this review.

I know it’s late to reply. Great analysis like usual.
I tend to think of the three characters – Sonny, Janie, and Bobby as the same characters in Racing In The Street. Sonny is Sonny, Janie is the girl with guy from LA who becomes very unsatisfied during the song, and Bobby is the protagonist of Racing, who’s point of view we see the song from.
Happy Anniversary!

Great analysis! I like both songs but I favor Missing over You’re Missing. To me the difference is that, in Missing, he doesn’t just long for the lost girl, it’s riddled him with so much anguish that he can hardly function. Her disappearance without a satisfying explanation, regardless of the circumstances or motivation, is like an offense. A crime. He feels so hurt and helpless over it that he won’t even roll over in bed to make himself more comfortable—or he can’t. It’s a powerful last line and very, very Bruce when he’s at his most morose (which is also usually his most honest, raw, and best, IMO). “I like awake, but I don’t move.” Haunting.
Happy New Year, Ken! Looking forward to another great year of E Street Shuffle.

I had a completely different interpretation of this song. The opposite actually. This is a guy who suffers from depression. Always. It’s his comfort zone. He’s actually not content unless he’s sad. And he’s reflecting on that. Recognizing that his behaviors only lead to more isolation. More loneliness. He’s pleading with sunshine to stay. He gets occasional glimpses of happiness before he abandons it because his safety is in isolation.
It’s a cautionary tale.
Bruce has talked about how one day he woke up and wondered, “Where is it all?” And he recognized that if he wanted happiness and a life he had to make it happen. And that’s when he and Patty decided to do it together.
Bruce promised he would be back soon… we´re waiting for you, Boss!

I regularly vacillate between this album and The River as my favorite of Bruce’s. But this one is definitely the most intimate. You almost feel embarrassed listening to it.

Ken, Nice work transcribing the lyrics. Even though they both “bop”, I prefer the “crossover” “Secret to the Blues” to the “The Band’s Just Bopping the Blues”–more bop and cleaner presentation by the
BSB/E Street hybrid. Thanks for the education.

This sleeper gem is an all-time fav that captures such a primal mood – Where the night gets sticky And the sky gets black. My take is that when Bruce had to reconcile between the fairytale ending he created with JP and the gritty, undeniable passion he discovered with PS (not nice, not clean) cheating on his bride with a bandmate was going to trash his image and disappoint his mom. So, if life is really only “one hard ride,” you better grab what’s real. He crossed his heart, as in being a double crosser.
One of my favorite tracks from The River!

Vietnam was a LIE. The lie was,’to fight for (our) freedom and to stop the spread of communism’. Vietnam had nothing to do with our freedom. I served one year in Vietnam, 1971-1972, involving airborne reconnaissance. I lived in air conditioned barracks the whole year and had a pool, tennis courts, basketball courts, etc., just a couple hundred yards from my barracks. In other words, I was not in a kill or be killed survival situation.
I was able to observe our military presence there more objectively and on a larger scale. I really felt that the Vietnamese people did NOT want us in their country. It seemed to me that we were only there to take up where the French government left off, when France pulled out of Vietnam. Even with a complete monopoly of military airspace over Vietnam, and much more powerful weapons, we could not stop the WILL OF THE PEOPLE. The people of Vietnam removed the shackles of colonialism, chose the government they wanted, and live peacefully…and they are also a trading partner of the U.S.
(Jeff)

I was too young to serve in Vietnam, and I didn’t know anyone who was killed there, but I have no doubt that visiting The Wall would still move me very deeply. I hope to see it someday. This song is just beautiful.

So why wouldn’t this song be inclusive, to include Native Americans? After all it says this land is YOUR land, this land is MY land……,, Isn’t that the essence of Native Americans beliefs that the land belongs no one exclusively, but to everybody?

I loved this, Ken. I went to many shows on the Rising Tour, usually was in the pit, and I did always hang out as people filed out. I very clearly remember hearing that slow bluesy version after each show. There was still enough noise around (and my hearing is “imperfect” enough) that I didn’t recognize it as “Countin’…,” but it was chilling and haunting and gorgeous nonetheless. Thanks for bringing that memory back!

Check out the lyrics in another song about a “New Jersey turnpike in the wee wee hours”, namely the Chuck Berry song You Can’t Catch Me . I think there are a lot of thematic and lyrical similarities between the two songs.

The song was finally performed as a world premiere on July 5, 2024 in Hannover, Germany during the European leg of Bruce’s 2024 world tour.

Maybe Bruce was thinking of Get Smart? The latter series had gadgets to spare. Or maybe I Spy just lay better over that musical phrase. (Similar to “speedball” instead of “fastball” in Glory Days.)

The ’60s TV references in this one remind me a little of Aretha Franklin’s 1967 classic “Save Me” (“Call in the Caped Crusader, Green Hornet, Kato too / I’m in so much trouble I don’t know what to do”).

At 17 years old, Live 1975 – 1985 was my first Springsteen purchase, day-of-release, after 2+ years of hearing/seeing half of BITUSA constantly on the radio and Friday Night Videos. An instant five-record deep dive into BS & E St. for $15? No-brainer. That album became my Bruce Bible, its acoustic “No Surrender” the gospel that brought me to faith. I never even heard the original album version until sometime later, so it doesn’t resonate as much with me. My life was always planned to follow a completely path than the one charted by any of Springsteen’s characters, but somehow I still identified with their hopes and dreams, the promise of freedom and release through rock and roll even if the dreams can’t actually come true. I can’t explain why the more mournful, thoughtful acoustic approach appeals more to me other than it was the first one, and my favorite performance on a record set I played daily in those final high school months.
1966 in the Martinique nightclub in Daytona Beach Turn On Your Lovelight was part of Duane and Greg’s set.
I’m assuming it’s Robbin, Mark, although I’m no expert on his voice.
Do we know who shares the vocals with Bruce in the Steel Mill-era take on “Turn On Your Love Light”? (It doesn’t sound like Steve.)

Is it a stretch to say Springsteen — who has written so poignantly and transparently about his personal demons, his country’s tremendous potential and its spectacular failures (domestically and abroad) — is Steinbeck’s spiritual successor? I think not. This American atheist finds timeless wisdom and the inspiration to keep fighting for what’s right in each artist’s work. Keep up the great work, Ken. (And maybe revisit The Grapes of Wrath when you have a chance — like George Orwell’s 1984 and Animal Farm, the book’s relevance could not be more obvious in America circa 2024.)
